ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I was able to develop my knowledge of Modern Hebrew. I learned how different verb structures operate in the past tense and developed new vocabulary and grammatical skills.
I learnt a lot of Hebrew.
hebrew! past tense of a lot of verbs, new binyanim, colors and clothes and overall practice speaking and fun!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There were many strengths to this course. The daily assignments were well organized and students knew exactly what was due every day, which is rare in an online course. I also really enjoyed the integration of music, poetry, commercials, and short readings into the live classes that helped develop our comprehension skills. Lastly, the homework provided good practice without being incredibly time-consuming. I cannot think of any real weaknesses in this course.
The material is very engaging. You'll have lots of fun watching Hebrew clips.
no comments on improvement, great course and space to learn. actually maybe get rid of the yoman or shorten the required length it's too hard and annoying to say so much

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: asynchronous was huge. i was intimidated by having to take a 5 day a week language class (even though it's only 50 minutes a day) and this was great to provide space and also feel like i have time and liberty in my schedule to figure out when i could/wanted to do things

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this course to any student who wants to continue their study of Hebrew. This course makes learning Hebrew enjoyable and low threat, the faculty is more than willing to help students, and the class is clear and organized. It moves at a reasonable pace (not too fast, but not too slow), and if you're willing to put in the work, it can be a really fun class.
Yes! You'll learn a lot of Hebrew in a really fun way!
absolutely! truly a great learning experience and a fun time :) would highly recommend it's just sweetness all around

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: asynchronous sessions where it was like homework that interacted with other students
